results.content:
One of my best takeaways from this was the de-romanticising of coding. Programming really is just knowing what you want to do, then doing very specific things to make that work, and then snapping them into place so they work as a whole. 

Programming has not come easy to me and I could not stomach another tutorial that had you doing math equations on the command line. I would recommend this tutorial for anyone who has the issue of having done tutorials, but don't know how to apply your new knowledge in the real world. 

The zip files with updated site contents is a real plus and if your code doesn't work after each lesson, you can download it and compare your code to RK's code. I have always been able to find my typos with this method.

results.content:
Giving review is something I don't do very often. 
But I have to do this, because the quantity and quality of content packed in this course is absolutely stunning.
I've started studying Web Development 6 months ago and, by far, this is the most challenging and fun Tutorial I've ever done.
It took me almost 1 month to finish the project, just because I wanted to fully absorb all the information given in the lessons.
I've had a couple of problems throughout the course, and I posted my questions on the Q&A section: Reece answered me in a few hours and he was super helpful not only in giving me the solution to my code errors, but also in pointing me out additional articles further expand the subject (in my case it was "Debugging in PHP").
If all this sound a bit "fanboyish" it's because I'm now officially a Reece Keeney fanboy, and I cannot wait to start his other courses.
Super great job my friend, thank you so much!
Paolo from Italy

results.content: I definitely did enjoy this course but I only had a couple of problems with it. The course says that no prior knowledge is needed other than HTML but that is not true. You need to know at least the syntax of PHP before doing this course or you will be confused at the beginning until you've done enough. The instructor doesn't really take the time to explain the syntax of the languages but more just goes straight into it. Another thing, is that I felt best practices were not used in this course. It felt as if the code was all over the place but that could just be PHP (I'm fairly new to PHP so this just may the case of the language). If you are an absolute beginner, I would not recommend the course but if you are a beginner looking for more PHP practice then I would definitely recommend this course. All in all though, good job to the instructor cause I definitely did learn a lot from this course!

results.content:
As an experienced Software Engineer, I've been hunting for courses that walk you through a project from start to finish to get new ideas and learn some PHP.  This course definitely was fun and informative.  I thought Kenny did a really great job with structuring the course and presenting it.

With that being said, I did see some areas that could be improved.

1. Code organization: Towards the end of the project there was a lot of copy-pasta and mixed up PHP, javascript, and HTML.  I found it difficult to see a clear separation of concerns.

2. Database: I personally used PDOs for my project with a singleton db class.  From what I've read online, that seems to be the suggested way to access the db in PHP, instead of the mysqli.

3. Password Hashing: I think md5 is no longer considered secure for password hashing and bcrypt is the commonly used algorithm for PHP.  Also, there is the new Argon2 that passed the hashing competition, available in the latest versions of PHP.  Might be interesting to look at.

Suggested Additions to the Course
1. Implementing an uploader for albums and/or songs that rips the metadata from the files and puts them into the database.

Suggested New Courses
1. Youtube Clone might be interesting.
2. Advanced PHP course with dependency injection, ORMs, class autoloaders (used in my project, really handy), best practices, design patterns.

Thanks!
results.content_html:
As an experienced Software Engineer, I've been hunting for courses that walk you through a project from start to finish to get new ideas and learn some PHP. This course definitely was fun and informative. I thought Kenny did a really great job with structuring the course and presenting it.

With that being said, I did see some areas that could be improved.

1. Code organization: Towards the end of the project there was a lot of copy-pasta and mixed up PHP, javascript, and HTML. I found it difficult to see a clear separation of concerns.

2. Database: I personally used PDOs for my project with a singleton db class. From what I've read online, that seems to be the suggested way to access the db in PHP, instead of the mysqli.

3. Password Hashing: I think md5 is no longer considered secure for password hashing and bcrypt is the commonly used algorithm for PHP. Also, there is the new Argon2 that passed the hashing competition, available in the latest versions of PHP. Might be interesting to look at.

Suggested Additions to the Course
1. Implementing an uploader for albums and/or songs that rips the metadata from the files and puts them into the database.

Suggested New Courses
1. Youtube Clone might be interesting.
2. Advanced PHP course with dependency injection, ORMs, class autoloaders (used in my project, really handy), best practices, design patterns.

Thanks!

All in all a high quality course that will push anyone unfamilar with advanced programming concepts to really step their game up.

results.content:
This was a great way to learn the basic functionality of web programming! I wish I would have registered for this course sooner. Reece's instructional methods and teaching styles are perfect for those learning the concepts of JavaScript, PHP, and MySQL. He goes over database concepts, basic front-end technique, data manipulation and back-end development. Troubleshooting and debugging was also really cool to follow along with. Wow, did I learn a lot! ANYONE wanting to know more about web development and hard coding web applications SHOULD and MUST take this course! It will require time and discipline but the knowledge and skills that you will retain are extremely beneficial! I've taken a few courses with Reece, the portfolio, this one, and I am currently taking the search engine. 

Thank you Reece! I look forward to applying this in the future! 

Happy New Years!!! :)

results.content:
Excellent course, good overview and process. I like how he doesn't linger on basic topics too long, although I would like to see more advanced explanations in part.

One constructive criticism, "once we get this working, I'll show you a better way of doing this" means we just typed a boat-load of stuff and it will have to be redone.

Why not say that upfront so we can decide if we want to type it through or just pay more attention to watching the 'wrong' way and then  just type up the 'right' way afterwards?  That's a minor complaint, since the teaching style is good and he keeps you engaged, even during the typing. 

Well done, Reece!

response.content:
Hi Paul :) 
Thanks so much for the kind words and also for the feedback! Regarding your feedback: when I show you one way of doing something and then after show you another way of doing it, it's usually so that beginners can do the easy way, but more advanced students can do the other way. It's also worth noting that we never change much between the two different pieces of code. So the two different techniques are usually fairly similar meaning 90% of the code you write in the first technique is still valid in the second one.

Thanks again for the review, always here if you need me! 
Reece

results.content:
I'm really enjoying this course. I was very intimidated with OOP, but the lecturer really knows how to ease you into it. The more I've started to realize just how much better OOP is, even though this course is certainly for beginners to help them understand the fundamentals. Once you start understanding data flow and where it needs to go and doesn't need to go, you really start to pick up OOP. For a while, I was going in circles, and I was going to give up but stuck with it and it's paying off. I've been used to procedural PHP, being taught this method at University and college. But courses like this for the money you pay really are priceless. I can't thank you enough for making this course. It gives me a little more confidence in programming and will help me evolve. I have nothing but the utmost respect for people doing courses like this to help other people out, it really does help. 

The course itself is very thorough and explained well. You might be a little intimidated when he goes into stuff you're not sure about. But don't give up, just keep going and the more you do it the more you start to understand how it works. I still think the best way to understand it is to create a mental picture in your head of how data flows, you could say the hierarchy of data importance. Anyone with some PHP procedural knowledge will love this course. This course is for people wanting to gain more knowledge of OOP, and you also get to create an awesome application. It's good to get out of that comfort zone and try new things, and this course is excellent at giving you the chance to evolve your skills.

results.content:
This is a phenomenal course.  Reece takes you step-by-step in building a fully-functional Spotify clone using PHP and JavaScript.  No feature is left out, and Reece leaves no stone unturned.  He takes you step-by-step through every line of code.  And if you're ever stuck, you can count on a thorough and speedy reply from him.

I also think it is great that the course delves into PHP classes, from a pretty early stage.  This makes for much better code, and OOP is hugely important to learn.

Those without ANY prior programming experience may find the course challenging, but I'm pretty confident that anyone can follow along (and always ask Reece for additional help if needed).  Even intermediate-to-advanced programmers will get a lot out of this course, especially how to handle audio with JavaScript.

In short: take this class.  You won't regret it.

results.content:
I loved the course and it was an amazing journey. Instructor cooperation was more than I could ask for.
As a beginner in programming, I can say this without any doubt that this course is absolutely necessary for anyone who want to learn programming not just web development. 

With due respect, I do have an suggestion that this course can become an ultimate source for learning programming if it also had exercises. For that to work out, udemy must have some way to increase progress by doing exercises in some course so that learners actually get inclined to doing it there, so I don't blame the instructor entirely for that.

I also have request for the instructor, please provide sources where you think we can learn the best and go deeper in the knowledge. That would be an added bonus.

Last there is an advice for people who want to buy this course, don't buy this course if you are complete beginner. Even though instructor explained every thing in complete detail without wasting time. It's way better if you have some background knowledge about programming. 
If you are going to buy it and you have experience then rest assured this course is the absolute necessary step you took toward your programming journey.

results.content:
Positives:
-Would definitely recommend the course as there's so much to get out of it.
-Reece is very responsive, a good communicator, and engaging throughout the course.
-Excellent idea for a course and great to be able to put your skills into something practical/useful.
-Reece explains everything he does.
-He doesn't edit and change code between videos
-If he makes a mistake, he will go through it there and then and explain what happened.
-I found that I've picked up loads- debugging, chrome tools, using PHP to interact with other languages, basic mysql, setting up a localhost, several 'ahh' that's neat tips/tricks, good habits.
-Sometimes it's just good to see how someone starts a project with folders and filenames.

Negatives:
Please note: these are based on my experiences of the course given my prior knowledge. You may be completely different.
I found the first 60-70% really good and it only started to dip towards the end. For some parts I ended up copying what he did and even though Reece does explain everything, there comes a point where copying something and listening to an explanation isn't as useful when the topics become a little more complex. I feel like the ajax other advanced parts need covering separately before you start using them in the project.
I also don't want this to sound harsh but Reece does make mistakes a little more frequently towards the end and it disrupted the flow of the project for me as I tried to get my head around some newer topics. 

I'm not convinced you should do this until you've covered basic HTML, basic CSS, basic javascript and basic PHP. Reece does warn that he won't go through the basics much too so you will have several "whaaaat?" moments if you're going in with just HTML knowledge.

Despite some negatives, I'm glad I took the course and I look forward to future courses from Reece :-)

response.content: Hi Ross! :) I'm glad that you enjoyed the course. Thanks so much for taking the time to share your feedback. All the best
response.content_html: Hi Ross! :) I'm glad that you enjoyed the course. Thanks so much for taking the time to share your feedback. All the best

results.content:
This course was a great challenge for me because my native language is not English, but Reece´s style and good performance made it so easy to understand everything. 

In my opinion, like many students have written, this course is not for beginners, but if you have been using JQuery, JavaScript, Ajax, PHP and MySQL for one year, this course is perfect for you to improve your skills in those languages and tools. 

As a personal challenge I tried to do the course with Vanilla JS (pure JS) instead of using JQuery, and I did it in a 95%. 

One of my suggestions to the course (not a complain) is to have a better ordered Javascript code. 

In some parts of the course (the latests) I felt that the code was confusing. I understand that in this kind of projects all the events of JavaScript play a fundamental role, but in my opinion the code could be better ordered. 

But, for me that is the only weak point of the course. And everything else is good and very useful. 

Congratulations to Reece for teaching us to build a more complex web project.

results.content:
This was an excellent course that exceeded my expectations. Reece has a very good teaching style and explains concepts and details very clearly. He is far and away the most responsive instructor I have come across on Udemy and answers questions in a timely manner.
 
The length of the videos lessons are mostly between 4-8 minutes, which is just about perfect. The music player project is interesting and enjoyable and a very engaging way to teach the underlying technologies. In addition it is fully functional and usable.
 
The course starts out basic but gets into some pretty complex aspects of CSS, PHP, SQL and JavaScript. Everything is explained clearly and in detail and I really like how Reece leaves in his mistakes along with how he troubleshoots, identifies, and fixes them. It is very real world and an important part of being a developer.
 
My only caveat would be that the course might prove a bit much for a complete beginner unless they are very motivated, as it does go into quite a bit of depth on a variety of technologies. But that is really a very minor point.  All in all I consider this the overall highest quality course I've taken on Udemy and Reece is an outstanding instructor. I give this course my highest recommendation.

results.content: This is easily the best web dev course I've taken. I can't recommend it enough. It's broken into short digestible sections that always focus on completing one part so you always feel like you're making good progress and it keeps motivation up. Reece explained the concepts well enough that I was able to complete quite a few of the tasks before having to watch the full-video first as I started to get more confident towards the 2nd half of the course.  I've done many other courses where you just copy someone's work only to realise you don't grasp the subject enough to know where to take it after that. Glad to say this course doesn't have that issue at all and I've found it straightforward adding in my own features while working through the course. Looking forward to trying one of Reece's other courses to keep building on the experience.
